chapter.title: Basic types
chapter.para: There are no primitive types in Ceylon, however, there are certain important types provided by the package lang. Many of these types support operators.

section.title: The void type
section.para: The class lang.Void is the root of the type system. All types are assignable to Void, which supports the the operator . (member selection), along with is (assignability).
section.programlisting: public abstract class Void {}

section.title: The Object type
section.para: User-written classes extend lang.Object and all interface types are assignable to lang.Object. Expressions of type Object support the binary operator === (identity equals). An Object may belong to collections. Expressions of type Object therefore support the binary operator in (in).

section.title: Callable references
section.para: The type lang.Callable represents an executable operation. Expressions of type Callable may be the subject of the argument specification operators () and {}.
An interceptor may be removed by invoking the returned method reference:
The following extension provides function composition, combining a Callable<Y,X> with a Callable<X,P...> to produce a Callable<Y,P...>:
For example:
section.programlisting: void logFormatted(Date date) = log.info(DateFormat('dd/mm/yyyy').format);
section.para: The next extension allows the first parameter of any function with multiple parameters to be curried, transforming a Callable<R,T,P...> into a Callable<Callable<R,P...>,T>:
For example:
section.programlisting: void info(String message) = log.message.partial(Level.info); void hello() = info.partial("Hello!");
section.para: This extension does the reverse, transforming a Callable<Callable<R,P...>,T> into a Callable<R,T,P...>:
For example:
section.programlisting: void say(Person p, String words) = Person.say.flatten;
section.para: Finally, this extension swaps the first and second formal parameter lists of a function with multiple parameter lists, transforming a Callable<Callable<R,Q...>,P...> into a Callable<Callable<R,P...>,Q...>:
For example:
section.programlisting: Float sqr(Float x) = Float.power.shuffle(2); void say(String words, Person p) = Person.say.shuffle.flatten;

section.title: Referenceable and assignable values
section.para: The class lang.Referenceable represents a value for which a reference can be obtained, allowing pass by reference semantics. Instances of Referenceable<T> are transparently assignable to T, according to the extension method getIt().
Note that lang.Referenceable is not a subclass of lang.Object.

The subtype lang.Assignable represents a reference to an assignable value, allowing pass by reference semantics for assignable values. Expressions of type Assignable support the binary operator := (assign).

section.title: Boolean values
section.para: The lang.Boolean class represents boolean values. Expressions of type Boolean support the binary ||, && and => operators and the unary ! operator, and inherit the binary |, &, ^ and unary ~ operators from Bits.

section.para: The interface lang.Case represents a type that may be used as a case in the switch construct.

section.title: Optional and null values
section.para: The class lang.Optional represents a value that may be null.

Expressions of type Object? support the binary operators ?. (nullsafe invoke) and ? (default), the unary operator exists, the unary operator $ (render) and the the binary operators == (equals) and != (not equals).
Note that lang.Optional is not a subtype of lang.Object.
If an optional value is not null, it is represented by an instance of the subclass lang.Something.

Non-optional values are transparently assignable to optional values, since Something<X> is an extension of X enabled in every compilation unit. Likewise, instances of Something<X> are transparently assignable to X.
If an optional value is null, it is represented by an instance of the subclass lang.Nothing.
The value Null.null is transparently assignable to optional values, since Nothing<X> is an extension of Null enabled in every compilation unit.
The decorator lang.NullCase allows null to appear as a case expression in a switch statement.

Note that Optional is not a reified type. The compiler erases all references to Optional<X> to X after performing type validation and before generating bytecode. The compiler also replaces references to Null.null with the Java null. Therefore, none of the extensions defined in this section are actually executed.

section.title: Usables
section.para: The interface lang.Usable represents an object with a lifecycle controlled by try.

section.title: Containers and categories
section.para: The interface lang.Container represents the abstract notion of an object that may be empty. Expressions of type Container? support the unary postfix operator nonempty.
The interface lang.Category represents the abstract notion of an object that contains other objects.
There is a mutable subtype, representing a category to which objects may be added.

section.title: Entries
section.para: The Entry class represents a pair of associated objects.
Entries may be constructed using the -> operator.

section.title: Correspondences
section.para: The interface lang.Correspondence represents the abstract notion of an object that maps value of one type to values of some other type. It supports the binary operator [key] (lookup).
A decorator allows retrieval of lists and sets of values.
There is a mutable subtype, representing a correspondence for which new mappings may be defined, and existing mappings modified. It provides for the use of element expressions in assignments.
A decorator allows addition of multiple Entrys.

section.title: Ordered values
section.para: The lang.Comparable interface represents totally ordered types, and supports the binary operators >, <, <=, >= and <=> (compare).

comment.para: TODO: should we support partial orders? Give Comparison an extra uncomparable value, or let compare() return null?
TODO: if so, why not just move compare() up to Object to simplify things?

section.para: The toplevel methods min() and max() return the minimum and maximum values of a list of Comparables.

The lang.Ordinal interface represents objects in a sequence, and supports the binary operator .. (range). In addition, variables support the postfix unary operators ++ (increment) and -- (decrement) and prefix unary operators ++ (successor) and -- (predecessor).

section.title: Bounded
section.para: The Bounded class represents a value from an upper-bounded list of natural numbers.

section.para: Ranges implement Sequence, therefore they support the join, subrange, contains and lookup operators, among others. Ranges may be constructed using the .. operator:
The following overloaded form is called for expressions like 0..5 where the arguments are instances of Bounded, with different dimensions.

section.para: UTF-32 Unicode Characters are represented by the following class:
String implements Sequence, and therefore supports the join, subrange, contains and lookup operators, among others. Any Character[] may be transparently converted to String.

section.para: A string template is represented by an instance of StringTemplate.

section.title: Bit strings
section.para: The interface Bits represents a fixed length string of boolean values, and supports the binary |, &, ^ and unary ~ operators.

section.title: Numbers
section.para: The lang.Number interface is the abstract supertype of all classes which represent numeric values.
The subtype lang.Numeric supports the binary operators +,-, *, /, **. In addition, mutable values of type Numeric support the compound assignment operators +=, -=, /=, *=.

comment.para: TODO: should plus() and times() accept varargs, to minimize method calls?
TODO: I suppose Numeric should not extend Comparable, since complex numbers are not comparable.

section.para: The subtype lang.Integral supports the binary operator %, and inherits the unary operators ++ and -- from Ordinal.
The type lang.Invertable supports the unary prefix - operator.
Five numeric types are built in:
lang.Natural represents 63 bit unsigned integers (including zero).

comment.para: TODO: the Numeric type is much more complicated because of Natural. As an alternative approach, we could replace Natural with a Binary type, and have Integer literals instead of Natural literals. I don't love this, because natural numbers are especially common in real applications.

section.para: lang.Integer represents 64 bit signed integers.
lang.Whole represents arbitrary-precision signed integers.
lang.Float represents 64 bit floating point values.
lang.Decimal represents arbitrary-precision and arbitrary-scale decimals.

section.title: Metamodel
section.para: The metamodel (reflection API) reifies the schema of a type, making it available to the program at runtime.
A Function represents a toplevel method.
An instance of Type represent a type: an interface, class or alias, together with type arguments.
An instance of Interface represents an interface.
section.programlisting: public interface Interface<X> satisfies Type<X> {}
section.para: An instance of Class represents a class.
An instance of Member represents a method or attribute.
A Method represents a method declaration.
An Attribute represents an attribute declaration.
An instance of MemberClass represents a member class.
A Parameter represents a formal parameter of a method or class.
An Annotated program element may be asked for a list of its annotation values.

section.title: Control expressions
section.para: The lang.assertion package defines support for assertions.
The lang.conditional package defines support for conditional expressions.
The lang.exceptional package defines support for exceptional expressions.
The lang.repetition package defines support for loops.
The lang.quantification package defines support for quantifiers.
The lang.comprehension.list package defines support for List comprehensions.
The lang.comprehension.map package defines support for Map comprehensions.
